comment_text: We used to use minute (uL amounts) of cadaverine and putrescine in protocols for cell culture media for culturing stem cells when I worked in labs years ago....I think they stop cells clumping and allow them to grow in suspension better....both chemicals really smell bad, putrescine is like rotten fish and cadaverine is somehow heavier with a touch of hydrogen sulphide in the aroma somehow

I found sodium hydroxide also works well instead of bicarbonate, with a little pyridoxal-5-phosphate as catalyst, in aqueous solution. (A little Cu2+ also makes a good catalyst.) I think the pyridoxal decomposed on heating, since the solution turned from yellow to green, but it still developed the right kind of smell. Afterwards it was simple to extract the cadaverine using isopropanol, which didn't mix with the aqueous layer, I'm just not sure how to separate the product from the solvent.
